Article.ArticleTitle: Photocatalytic Oxidation of Carbon Monoxide Using Synergy of Redox-Separated Photocatalyst and Ozone.

AbstractText: Separating the redox centers of photocatalysts is the most promising strategy to enhance photocatalytic oxidation efficiency. Herein, I investigate a site-selective loading of Pt on facet-engineered TiO<sub>2</sub> to achieve carbon monoxide (CO) oxidation at room temperature. Spatially loaded Pt on {101} facets of TiO<sub>2</sub> attracts photoinduced electrons efficiently. Thereby, oxygen dissociation is facilitated on the Pt surface, which is confirmed by enhanced oxidation of CO by 2.4 times compared to the benchmark of Pt/TiO<sub>2</sub>. The remaining holes on TiO<sub>2</sub> can be utilized for the oxidation of various gaseous pollutants. Specifically, gaseous ozone, which is present in indoor and ambient air, is converted to a hydroxyl radical by reacting with the hole; thus, the poisoned Pt surface is continuously cleaned during the CO oxidation, as confirmed by in situ diffuse reflectance infrared transform spectroscopy. While randomly loaded Pt can act as recombination center, reducing photocatalytic activity, redox-separated photocatalyst enhances charge separation, boosting CO oxidation and catalyst regeneration via simultaneous ozone decomposition.
